speaker: James
text: [dry] The West's 'romance' with free trade, Elena. The article suggests it was less romance, more a temporary convenience.

speaker: Elena
text: Oh, come on. That's incredibly cynical. Free trade lifted millions globally, you can't deny the benefits.

speaker: James
text: Did it, or did it just redistribute wealth more effectively for whoever was winning at the time? The historical arc is telling.

speaker: Elena
text: Telling how?

speaker: James
text: From the 1400s, it was mercantilism. States granting monopolies, like the East India Company. Violently anti-competitive.

speaker: Elena
text: But that's ancient history. We evolved beyond that.

speaker: James
text: Did we? The British only championed free trade after their Industrial Revolution. They could produce everything cheaper.

speaker: Elena
text: [surprised] You're saying Adam Smith and Ricardo were just... a smokescreen?

speaker: James
text: Not entirely, but their ideas aligned perfectly with Britain's economic dominance. Free trade became an extension of mercantilism, just with a different mechanism.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a convenient reading of history, James.

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] Convenient, perhaps, but effective. They used force to break into markets. Think the Opium Wars in 1839. China didn't want their opium, Britain sent the Royal Navy.

speaker: Elena
text: That's... actually devastating. A stark reminder of colonialism's underbelly.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. Then the US took up the mantle after WW1, pushing free trade when they dominated sectors.

speaker: Elena
text: But that was different. That wasn't about forcing markets open with gunboats. It was about creating a global system.

speaker: James
text: A system that started to fray when Japan and West Germany began producing better, cheaper goods in the 1980s. Protectionist sentiments emerged.

speaker: Elena
text: But then the Soviet Union collapsed, and China joined the WTO in 2001. That ushered in a golden age of sorts, didn't it? A genuine win-win.

speaker: James
text: For a while, yes. Cheap goods for the West, jobs for China. The classic Ricardian comparative advantage.

speaker: Elena
text: Exactly! Millions lifted out of poverty. That's the real story.

speaker: James
text: Until it turned into a gigantic trap, as the article puts it. Western companies trained the Chinese, transferred IP, often forcibly.

speaker: Elena
text: [frustrated] But those companies went in knowing the terms! They chased the market, willingly. You can't blame China for playing the long game.

speaker: James
text: And for industrial espionage. We've seen this before, haven't we? Our article 'China Has Many Of The Characteristics Of An Emerging Colonial Power' explores this too.

speaker: Elena
text: You're comparing China's current actions to historical colonialism?

speaker: James
text: They lost their monopolies on silk in 552 AD, porcelain in the 1700s, tea in the 1800s. All stolen. Now they're doing the reverse.

speaker: Elena
text: Wait. You're saying China is just giving the West a taste of its own historical medicine?

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] The historical echoes are undeniable. China's 'Made in China 2025' policy aims to dominate high-value sectors: AI, EVs, biotech. No more sticking to low-cost goods.

speaker: Elena
text: So, the theory of comparative advantage... it's breaking down. China's not just making our cheap plastic toys anymore.

speaker: James
text: It's the world's largest manufacturer and exporter. $12.7 trillion economy in 2019. Exports jumped from $21 billion in 1980 to $2.49 trillion by 2017. They're winning.

speaker: Elena
text: That's... actually very hard to argue with. The numbers are stark.

speaker: James
text: Hard to argue with. The West's 'luck' is indeed running out, as another of our articles states.

speaker: Elena
text: So Trump's tariffs, Europe's blocking Chinese acquisitions... it's not just economic nationalism. It's an admission free trade isn't working for us anymore.

speaker: James
text: It's a return to self-interest. The 'romance' ends when the partner starts out-competing you across the board.

speaker: Elena
text: And the implications for the global balance of power are... immense. More trade wars, then?

speaker: James
text: If history is a guide, yes. The 1400s had their own version of trade protection. We're just swapping spices for silicon chips.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a rather bleak outlook, James. For everyone.
